thread.title: Armed Forces charities face funding shortfall as Shoreham disaster puts air shows under threat
thread.title_full: Armed Forces charities face funding shortfall as Shoreham disaster puts air shows under threat

author: Gordon Rayner
title: Armed Forces charities face funding shortfall as Shoreham disaster puts air shows under threat
text:
Aviation Armed Forces charities face funding shortfall as Shoreham disaster puts air shows under threat Air show organiser says some smaller displays will have to be cancelled in 2016 because of expected rise in insurance costs The Red Arrows are a major draw at air shows up and down the country Photo: SAC Tim Laurence/MoD/Crown Copyright By Gordon Rayner , Chief Reporter 10:00PM BST 13 Sep 2015 Follow 
Armed Forces charities fear they will be hundreds of thousands of pounds worse off next year because air shows are likely to be cancelled in the wake of the Shoreham air disaster. 
Organisers of air displays are bracing themselves for a major hike in insurance premiums as a result of the Hawker Hunter crash that claimed 11 lives , which will make some shows financially unviable. 
• The victims, the crash, the pilot, the aftermath: Everything we know about Shoreham Air Show crash 
Each year around 500 air displays take place in Britain, most of which raise money for charity. 
They include Shoreham, the air show of the Royal Air Forces Association, Waddington in Lincolnshire, which raises money for the RAF Benevolent Fund, and the Royal International Air Tattoo at Fairford in Gloucestershire, which benefits the RAF Charitable Trust. 
A Hawker Hunter crashed at the Shoreham air show, killing 11 Photo: Eddie Mitchell 
Paul Beaver, a member of the British Air Display Association, said: “We could find that next year the air show programme will be smaller than it is at the moment. 
“Across the country there is usually a choice of six or seven air shows every weekend and that number will decrease next year. 
“Insurance premiums will be examined over the course of the winter in the light of Shoreham, though a lot of underwriters may wait until the full results of the Air Accidents Investigation Branch are known, which will take months. If there is uncertainty, some organisers may decide to cancel shows to be on the safe side.” 
Mr Beaver, who organises the annual Chalk Valley History Festival air show in Wiltshire, has already had to cancel a Battle of Britain 75th anniversary flypast over London by 20 Spitfires planned for September 20 after he was told the event would have to be insured for £250 million. 
He added: “Air shows are a business and any profit tends to be a charity donation. If there is a risk that the event will make a loss because of increased insurance costs, they will not go ahead. 
The 11 victims of the Shoreham air disaster 
“We’re all just hoping the insurance industry will be pragmatic and accept that the 63-year period between Shoreham and the previous fatalities among members of the public at an air show is a significant [safety record].” 
The RAFBF and RAFA each received £135,000 from the Waddington show alone in 2013, and in 2014 the Shoreham Air Show raised £208,000 for RAFA. Interactive: PLANE LOOP 
The RAF Charitable Trust, a grant-giving charity, relies almost totally on air shows for its income. Last year, £580,000 of its £690,000 income came from the Royal International Air Tattoo, with another £65,000 coming from the RAF Cosford Air Show, which donated the same amount to the RAFBF and RAFA, as well as the Royal Air Force Museum. 
There is no suggestion any of these major air shows are under threat, but scores of smaller shows also raise money for the hundreds of forces charities. 
Charlotte Mellor sings on a Battle of Britain 75th anniversary CD to raise money for Forces charities Photo: Jim Dooley 
Jim Dooley, head of fundraising for the Bomber Command Memorial in London and a fundraiser for the RAF Benevolent Fund, said the problems have already begun. 
Video grab showing moments before the Hawker Hunter plane crashed on A27 
Moments before the Hawker Hunter jet comes down on the A27 during the Shoreham Airshow in West Sussex Photo: Chris Watkins 
Moment the Hawker Hunter fighter jet crashed on the A27 during the Shoreham Air Show Photo: Terry Smith 
Mr Dooley, who has raised more than £500,000 by taking and selling air-to-air photographs of vintage aeroplanes, said: “Normally I will do about four flights a year taking pictures to sell for charity, but so far this year I have only been able to do one. 
“Everyone is worried about insurance, so we are going to have to find different ways of raising money from now on.” 
Mr Dooley, who had a career as a pop singer before he became a fundraiser, has written a song for the Battle of Britain 75th anniversary, called If You Hadn’t Done What You Did , sung by Charlotte Mellor, the 18-year-old daughter of an RAF officer, to raise money for the two charities he supports. Shoreham Air Show disaster How the events unfolded Saturday, August 22 Thousands gather at the Shoreham Airshow to mark the 75th anniversary of the Battle of Britain. At 1.20pm the scene turns to horror as a 1950's Hawker Hunter plane crashes into a busy A27 bypass, hitting at least four cars - including a wedding limousine Loss of control The pilot, 51-year-old former RAF officer Andy Hill, carries out a loop manoeuvre high in the air before smashing into the road in a huge fireball after failing to pull up in time Pilot wrestles with the controls Moments before the point of impact the pilot appears to be trying to pull up from the A27 as it plummets towards the dual carriageway, where dozens of onlookers can be seen watching the display Plane strikes the A27 The aicraft ploughs across the busy road just yards from cars and a group of people, its cockpit canopy open and wing ablaze, engulfing traffic lights, roadwork cones and signs in a huge ball of fire. Burning debris is also visible high in the air Cloud of death Dazed witnesses survey the scene on the A27 as smoke billows into the sky from several vehicles and people appear to try to help victims. Trail of destruction Seven people are confirmed dead with the toll expected to rise and a further two are taken to hospital, one with life threatening injuries. 14 people are treated at the scene Yet another tragedy It is the sixth disaster at an air show over the past seven years, resulting in a total of six deaths before Saturday’s incident, including a fatality in 2007 at the Shoreham event
